file.content:
#!/bin/bash
# Script to migrate ALL environment variables to skogai namespace in skogcli
# Can split into separate namespaces later if needed

echo "üöÄ Starting migration of environment variables to skogcli (skogai namespace)..."
echo ""

# ----------------------------------------------------------------------------
# Development Paths
# ----------------------------------------------------------------------------
echo "üìÅ Setting up development paths..."
skogcli config set skogai.env.UV_CACHE_DIR "/mnt/extra/uv"
skogcli config set skogai.env.UV_TOOL_DIR "/mnt/extra/uv-tools"
skogcli config set skogai.env.NVM_DIR "/mnt/extra/nvm"
skogcli config set skogai.env.GOPATH "/mnt/extra/go"
skogcli config set skogai.env.CRYPTOGRAPHY_OPENSSL_NO_LEGACY "1"

# ----------------------------------------------------------------------------
# Editor & Browser
# ----------------------------------------------------------------------------
echo "üìù Setting up editor and browser..."
skogcli config set skogai.env.EDITOR "nvim"
skogcli config set skogai.env.BROWSER "firefox-nightly"
skogcli config set skogai.env.PAGER "cat"

# ----------------------------------------------------------------------------
# Argc Completions
# ----------------------------------------------------------------------------
echo "üîß Setting up argc completions..."
skogcli config set skogai.env.ARGC_COMPLETIONS_ROOT "/home/skogix/.local/src/argc-completions"
skogcli config set skogai.env.ARGC_COMPLETIONS_PATH "\$ARGC_COMPLETIONS_ROOT/completions/linux:\$ARGC_COMPLETIONS_ROOT/completions"

# ----------------------------------------------------------------------------
# API Keys - OpenRouter/OpenAI
# ----------------------------------------------------------------------------
echo "üîë Setting up API keys..."
skogcli config set skogai.env.OPENROUTER_API_KEY "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"
skogcli config set skogai.env.OPENAI_API_KEY "\$OPENROUTER_API_KEY"
skogcli config set skogai.env.OPENAI_BASE_URL "https://openrouter.ai/api/v1"

# Anthropic
skogcli config set skogai.env.ANTHROPIC_API_KEY "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"
skogcli config set skogai.env.CLAUDE_CODE_OAUTH_TOKEN "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"

# Other Services
skogcli config set skogai.env.PERPLEXITY_API_KEY "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"
skogcli config set skogai.env.LETTA_API_KEY "OWMwYTNhYTItYTJmNi00YmIxLTg5ZGEtYjk2ZmMyOTY4ZWVkOmNlOTM5ZmVmLTRiZTktNDY0ZC05YmM2LTRlZGEzMWI5OTQ0Mw=="
skogcli config set skogai.env.TAVILY_API_KEY "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"
skogcli config set skogai.env.EXA_API_KEY "5d7cdd99-f7f8-4c36-b104-169c61cc0554"
skogcli config set skogai.env.DUCK_API_KEY "FTEwwp2XxGUUA4mMZP1UhikQ"

content.content:
RCUP(1)                      General Commands Manual                    RCUP(1)

NAME
       rcup ‚Äî update and install dotfiles managed by rcm

SYNOPSIS
       rcup   [-CfhiKkqVv]   [-B   hostname]   [-d   dir]  [-g]  [-I  excl_pat]
            [-S excl_pat] [-s excl_pat] [-t tag] [-U  excl_pat]  [-u  excl_pat]
            [-x excl_pat] [files ...]

DESCRIPTION
       This  is  a  program to update and install personal dotfiles. These dot‚Äê
       files are managed in a separate directory. Use  rcup  to  install  files
       from your dotfiles directories or from host- or tag-specific directories
       within.

       See ‚ÄúDIRECTORY LAYOUT‚Äù for details on the directory layout.

       It supports these options:

       -B HOSTNAME  treat  host-HOSTNAME as the host-specific directory instead
                    of computing it.

       -C           copy the files instead of symlinking them.

       -d DIR       install dotfiles from the DIR.  This can be specified  mul‚Äê
                    tiple times.

       -f           if  the  rc  file already exists in your home directory but
                    does not match the file in your dotfiles directory,  remove
                    the rc file then create the symlink.

       -g           print to stdout a standalone shell script that will run the
                    rcup command as specified.  Nothing on your filesystem will
                    be modified by rcup when this flag is passed.

       -h           show usage instructions.

       -I EXCL_PAT  install rc files that match EXCL_PAT despite being excluded
                    by  the  -x  flag or a setting in rcrc(5).  This can be re‚Äê
                    peated with  additional  patterns.  See  lsrc(1),  ‚ÄúEXCLUDE
                    PATTERN‚Äù, for more details.

       -i           if  the  rc  file already exists in your home directory but
                    does not match the file in your dotfiles directory,  prompt
                    for how to handle it. This is the default.

       -K           skip pre- and post-hooks.

       -k           run  pre-  and  post-hooks (see ‚ÄúDIRECTORY LAYOUT‚Äù for more
                    details on hooks). This is the default.

       -S EXCL_PAT  any rc file that matches EXCL_PAT is installed using a sym‚Äê
                    link even if it is a directory.  This  option  can  be  re‚Äê
                    peated.

       -s EXCL_PAT  any  file  that matches EXCL_PAT is installed as normal, in
                    accordance with the ‚ÄúALGORITHM‚Äù section below. This is  the
                    opposite of -S.  This option can be repeated.

       -t TAG       install dotfiles according to TAG.

       -U EXCL_PAT  any  rc  file  that matches EXCL_PAT is installed without a
                    leading dot. This option can be repeated. See the  documen‚Äê
                    tation of the -U option in lsrc(1) for more information.

       -u EXCL_PAT  any rc file that matches EXCL_PAT is installed with a lead‚Äê
                    ing  dot.  This  is the opposite of -U.  This option can be
                    repeated. This is the default. See the documentation of the
                    -u option in lsrc(1) for more information.

       -q           decrease verbosity.

       -V           show the version number.

       -v           increase verbosity.  This can be repeated  for  extra  ver‚Äê
                    bosity.  Verbose messages are printed to stderr.

       -x EXCL_PAT  do  not  install rc files that match EXCL_PAT.  This can be
                    repeated with additional patterns.  See  lsrc(1),  ‚ÄúEXCLUDE
                    PATTERN‚Äù, for more details.

       files        only install the specified file(s)

DIRECTORY LAYOUT
       Any  non-dot  non-meta  file  or directory under your dotfiles directory
       will be installed as a dotfile. For example, .dotfiles/zshrc will be in‚Äê
       stalled into ~/.zshrc .

       Files are installed as symlinks. Directories are installed by making di‚Äê
       rectories. The -C flag causes files to be installed as copies instead of
       symlinks. The COPY_ALWAYS option in rcrc(5) can be used  to  list  files
       that  must only be copied. Copied files are not updated in your dotfiles
       directory.

       Three meta files  are  supported:  host-specific  files,  tagged  files,
       hooks.

       Host-specific  files go in a directory named for the host, prefixed with
       host-.  For example, .dotfiles/host-scarlett contains files specific  to
       the  computer  with  hostname scarlett, and these files will only be in‚Äê
       stalled on the computer with hostname scarlett.

       Tagged files go in a directory named for the tag,  prefixed  with  tag-.
       Therefore,  files  under  .dotfiles/tag-git  are only installed when in‚Äê
       stalling using the git tag.

       Hooks go in a directory named hooks.  Two hooks are supported  by  rcup:
       pre-up  and  post-up.  These go in files or directories with predictable
       filenames:  .dotfiles/hooks/pre-up   and   .dotfiles/hooks/post-up,   or
       .dotfiles/hooks/pre-up/*  and  .dotfiles/hooks/post-up/*.   These  files
       must be executable. They are run every time rcup is run,  and  therefore
       must be idempotent.

       Hooks  will  be  executed  one at a time, sorted alphabetically. For in‚Äê
       stance, hooks/pre-up/animals will run before hooks/pre-up/aquariums, and
       hooks/pre-up/4-eyes will run before hooks/post-up/2-u-nothing-compares.

ALGORITHM
       It is instructive to understand the process rcup uses when synchronizing
       your rc files:

       1.   The pre-up hook is run.

       2.   All non-host, non-tag files without a dot prefix are  symlinked  to
            the  dotted filename in your home directory. So, .dotfiles/tigrc is
            symlinked to ~/.tigrc.

       3.   All non-host, non-tag directories have their  structure  copied  to
            your  home  directory, then a non-dotted symlink is created within.
            So  for  example,  .dotfiles/vim/autoload/haskell.vim  causes   the
            ~/.vim/autoload  directory  to be created, then haskell.vim is sym‚Äê
            linked within.

       4.   Steps (2) and (3) are applied to  host-specific  files.  These  are
            files under a directory named host-$HOSTNAME.

       5.   Steps  (2)  and  (3)  are  applied to tag-specific files. These are
            files under directories named tag-$TAG_NAME, where $TAG_NAME is the
            name of each specified tag in turn, taken from the command line  or
            from rcrc(5).

       6.   The post-up hook is run.

ENVIRONMENT
       RCRC  User configuration file. Defaults to ~/.rcrc.

FILES
       ~/.dotfiles ~/.rcrc

SEE ALSO
       lsrc(1), mkrc(1), rcdn(1), rcrc(5), rcm(7)

AUTHORS
       rcup is maintained by Mike Burns <mburns@thoughtbot.com> and thoughtbot:
       http://thoughtbot.com

GNU                              July 28, 2013                          RCUP(1)

RCM(7)                  Miscellaneous Information Manual                 RCM(7)

NAME
       rcm ‚Äî dotfile management

SYNOPSIS
       lsrc
       mkrc
       rcdn
       rcup

DESCRIPTION
       The  rcm  suite of tools is for managing dotfiles directories. This is a
       directory containing all the .*rc files in your home directory  (.zshrc,
       .vimrc,  and  so  on).   These files have gone by many names in history,
       such as ‚Äúrc files‚Äù because they typically end in rc  or  ‚Äúdotfiles‚Äù  be‚Äê
       cause they begin with a period.

       This  suite  is useful for committing your rc files to a central reposi‚Äê
       tory to share, but it also scales to a more complex  situation  such  as
       multiple source directories shared between computers with some host-spe‚Äê
       cific or task-specific files.

       This  guide  serves  as  a  tutorial motivating the suite. For a list of
       quick reference documentation see the ‚ÄúSEE ALSO‚Äù section below.

QUICK START FOR EXISTING DOTFILES DIRECTORIES
       This section is for those who already have an existing  dotfiles  direc‚Äê
       tory;  this  directory  is  ~/.dotfiles;  the directory only contains rc
       files; and these rc filenames do  not  begin  with  a  period.  See  the
       caveats below if this is not you.

       1.   Dry  run  with lsrc(1).  Look for anything unexpected in here, such
            as ~/.install or ~/.Makefile, or an empty list of dotfiles.

                  lsrc

       2.   Update any symlinks with rcup(1).  This is likely  to  do  nothing,
            since your dotfiles already exist.

                  rcup -v

       3.   When  necessary,  add  new  rc files to the dotfiles directory with
            mkrc(1).

                  mkrc ~/.tigrc

            In the other direction, you can use rcup(1) to create the  symlinks
            from ~/.dotfiles to your home directory.

                  rcup tigrc

   COMMON PROBLEM: EXISTING INSTALL SCRIPTS
       Many existing dotfile directories have scripts named install or Makefile
       in the directory. This will cause a ~/.install or ~/.Makefile symlink to
       be  created  in  your home directory. Use an exclusion pattern to ignore
       these.

             rcup -x install -x Rakefile -x Makefile -x install.sh

   COMMON PROBLEM: DOTTED FILENAMES IN DOTFILES DIRECTORY
       A less common situation is for all the filenames in your dotfiles direc‚Äê
       tory to be prefixed with a period. These files are skipped  by  the  rcm
       suite,  and  thus  would result in nothing happening. The only option in
       this case is to rename all the files, for example by using a shell  com‚Äê
       mand like the following.

             find  ~/.dotfiles  -name  '.*'  -exec  echo  mv  {} ‚Äòecho {} | sed
             's/.//'‚Äò ;

       Note that this will break any existing symlinks. Those can be safely re‚Äê
       moved using the rcdn(1) command.

             rcdn -v

   COMMON PROBLEM: DOTFILES DIRECTORY NOT IN ~/.dotfiles
       This all assumes that your dotfiles directory is ~/.dotfiles.  If it  is
       elsewhere  and  you do not want to move it you can use the -d DIR option
       to rcup(1) or modify DOTFILES_DIRS in rcrc(5).

             rcup -d configs -v

   COMMON PROBLEM: CONFIGURATION FILES/DIRECTORIES WITHOUT DOTS
       By default, the rcm suite will prefix every file and directory  it  man‚Äê
       ages  with  a  dot.  If  that is not desired, for example in the case of
       ~/bin or ~/texmf, you can add that file  or  directory  to  UNDOTTED  in
       rcrc(5) or use the -U option. For example:

             mkrc -U bin

QUICK START FOR EMPTY DOTFILES DIRECTORIES
       This section is for those who do not have an existing dotfiles directory
       and whose dotfiles are standard.

       1.   Add your rc files to a dotfiles directory with mkrc(1).

                  mkrc .zshrc .gitconfig .tigrc

       2.   Synchronize your home directory with rcup(1)

                  rcup -v

       This  will  give you a directory named ~/.dotfiles with your dotfiles in
       it. Your original dotfiles will be symlinks into this directory. For ex‚Äê
       ample, ~/.zshrc will be a symlink to ~/.dotfiles/zshrc.

TAGGED DOTFILES
       This suite becomes more powerful if you share  your  dotfiles  directory
       between  computers, either because multiple people share the same direc‚Äê
       tory or because you have multiple computers.

       If you share the dotfiles directory between people, you may end up  with
       some  irrelevant or even incorrect rc files. For example, you may have a
       .zshrc while your other contributor has a .bashrc.  This  situation  can
       be handled with tags.

       1.   A  tag is a directory under the dotfiles directory that starts with
            the letters tag-.  We can handle the  competing  shell  example  by
            making a tag-zsh directory and moving the .zshrc file into it using
            mkrc(1) and passing the -t option.

                  mkrc -t zsh .zshrc

       2.   When  updating  with  rcup(1) you can pass the -t option to include
            the tags you want. This can also be set in the  rcrc(5)  configura‚Äê
            tion file with the TAGS variable.

                  rcup -t zsh

MULTIPLE DOTFILE DIRECTORIES
       Another common situation is combining multiple dotfiles directories that
       people  have  shared  with  you.  For  this  we  have the -d flag or the
       DOTFILES_DIRS option in .rcrc.

       The following rcup invocation will go in sequence through the three dot‚Äê
       files directories, updating any symlinks as needed. Any  overlapping  rc
       files  will use the first result, not the last; that is, .dotfiles/vimrc
       will take precedence over marriage-dotfiles/vimrc.

             rcup -d .dotfiles -d marriage-dotfiles -d thoughtbot-dotfiles

       An exclusion pattern can be tied to a specific dotfiles directory.

             rcup -d .dotfiles -d work-dotfiles -x 'work-dotfiles:powrc'

HOST-SPECIFIC DOTFILES
       You can also mark host-specific files. This will go by the hostname. The
       rcrc(5) configuration file is a popular candidate  for  a  host-specific
       file,  since  the tags and dotfile directories listed in there are often
       specific to a single machine.

             mkrc -o .rcrc

       If your hostname is difficult to compute, or you otherwise want to use a
       different hostname, you can use the -B flag.

             mkrc -B eggplant .rcrc

       macOS users should see the ‚ÄúBUGS‚Äù section for more details.

STANDALONE INSTALLATION SCRIPT
       The rcup(1) tool can be used to generate a portable shell  script.   In‚Äê
       stead  of  running  a  command such as ln(1) or rm(1), it will print the
       command to stdout.  This is controlled with the -g flag.  Note that this
       will generate a script to create an exact replica  of  the  synchroniza‚Äê
       tion, including tags, host-specific files, and dotfiles directories.

             env RCRC=/dev/null rcup -B 0 -g > install.sh

       Using  the  above command, you can now run install.sh to install (or re-
       install) your rc files.  The install.sh script can  be  stored  in  your
       dotfiles directory, copied between computers, and so on.

RATIONALE
       The  rcm suite was built as an abstraction over the shell, Ruby, Python,
       and make scripts people were writing and sharing. It is intended to  run
       on  any unix system and support the range from simple to complex dotfile
       directories.

       As such, this suite is useful as a common  base.  Through  this  we  can
       share tools and develop this further as a first-class entity. It is also
       our hope that a common set of tools will encourage others to share their
       dotfiles, too.

FILES
       ~/.dotfiles ~/.rcrc

SEE ALSO
       lsrc(1), mkrc(1), rcdn(1), rcup(1), rcrc(5)

AUTHORS
       rcm  is maintained by Mike Burns <mburns@thoughtbot.com> and thoughtbot:
       http://thoughtbot.com

BUGS
       For macOS systems, we strongly encourage the use of the  HOSTNAME  vari‚Äê
       able  in  your rcrc(5).  We use the hostname(1) program to determine the
       unique identifier for the host. This program is not specified  by  POSIX
       and can vary by system. On macOS, the hostname is unpredictable, and can
       even change as part of the DHCP handshake.

RCM(7)                  Miscellaneous Information Manual                 RCM(7)

NAME
       rcm ‚Äî dotfile management

SYNOPSIS
       lsrc
       mkrc
       rcdn
       rcup

DESCRIPTION
       The  rcm  suite of tools is for managing dotfiles directories. This is a
       directory containing all the .*rc files in your home directory  (.zshrc,
       .vimrc,  and  so  on).   These files have gone by many names in history,
       such as ‚Äúrc files‚Äù because they typically end in rc  or  ‚Äúdotfiles‚Äù  be‚Äê
       cause they begin with a period.

       This  suite  is useful for committing your rc files to a central reposi‚Äê
       tory to share, but it also scales to a more complex  situation  such  as
       multiple source directories shared between computers with some host-spe‚Äê
       cific or task-specific files.

       This  guide  serves  as  a  tutorial motivating the suite. For a list of
       quick reference documentation see the ‚ÄúSEE ALSO‚Äù section below.

QUICK START FOR EXISTING DOTFILES DIRECTORIES
       This section is for those who already have an existing  dotfiles  direc‚Äê
       tory;  this  directory  is  ~/.dotfiles;  the directory only contains rc
       files; and these rc filenames do  not  begin  with  a  period.  See  the
       caveats below if this is not you.

       1.   Dry  run  with lsrc(1).  Look for anything unexpected in here, such
            as ~/.install or ~/.Makefile, or an empty list of dotfiles.

                  lsrc

       2.   Update any symlinks with rcup(1).  This is likely  to  do  nothing,
            since your dotfiles already exist.

                  rcup -v

       3.   When  necessary,  add  new  rc files to the dotfiles directory with
            mkrc(1).

                  mkrc ~/.tigrc

            In the other direction, you can use rcup(1) to create the  symlinks
            from ~/.dotfiles to your home directory.

                  rcup tigrc

   COMMON PROBLEM: EXISTING INSTALL SCRIPTS
       Many existing dotfile directories have scripts named install or Makefile
       in the directory. This will cause a ~/.install or ~/.Makefile symlink to
       be  created  in  your home directory. Use an exclusion pattern to ignore
       these.

             rcup -x install -x Rakefile -x Makefile -x install.sh

   COMMON PROBLEM: DOTTED FILENAMES IN DOTFILES DIRECTORY
       A less common situation is for all the filenames in your dotfiles direc‚Äê
       tory to be prefixed with a period. These files are skipped  by  the  rcm
       suite,  and  thus  would result in nothing happening. The only option in
       this case is to rename all the files, for example by using a shell  com‚Äê
       mand like the following.

             find  ~/.dotfiles  -name  '.*'  -exec  echo  mv  {} ‚Äòecho {} | sed
             's/.//'‚Äò ;

       Note that this will break any existing symlinks. Those can be safely re‚Äê
       moved using the rcdn(1) command.

             rcdn -v

   COMMON PROBLEM: DOTFILES DIRECTORY NOT IN ~/.dotfiles
       This all assumes that your dotfiles directory is ~/.dotfiles.  If it  is
       elsewhere  and  you do not want to move it you can use the -d DIR option
       to rcup(1) or modify DOTFILES_DIRS in rcrc(5).

             rcup -d configs -v

   COMMON PROBLEM: CONFIGURATION FILES/DIRECTORIES WITHOUT DOTS
       By default, the rcm suite will prefix every file and directory  it  man‚Äê
       ages  with  a  dot.  If  that is not desired, for example in the case of
       ~/bin or ~/texmf, you can add that file  or  directory  to  UNDOTTED  in
       rcrc(5) or use the -U option. For example:

             mkrc -U bin

QUICK START FOR EMPTY DOTFILES DIRECTORIES
       This section is for those who do not have an existing dotfiles directory
       and whose dotfiles are standard.

       1.   Add your rc files to a dotfiles directory with mkrc(1).

                  mkrc .zshrc .gitconfig .tigrc

       2.   Synchronize your home directory with rcup(1)

                  rcup -v

       This  will  give you a directory named ~/.dotfiles with your dotfiles in
       it. Your original dotfiles will be symlinks into this directory. For ex‚Äê
       ample, ~/.zshrc will be a symlink to ~/.dotfiles/zshrc.

TAGGED DOTFILES
       This suite becomes more powerful if you share  your  dotfiles  directory
       between  computers, either because multiple people share the same direc‚Äê
       tory or because you have multiple computers.

       If you share the dotfiles directory between people, you may end up  with
       some  irrelevant or even incorrect rc files. For example, you may have a
       .zshrc while your other contributor has a .bashrc.  This  situation  can
       be handled with tags.

       1.   A  tag is a directory under the dotfiles directory that starts with
            the letters tag-.  We can handle the  competing  shell  example  by
            making a tag-zsh directory and moving the .zshrc file into it using
            mkrc(1) and passing the -t option.

                  mkrc -t zsh .zshrc

       2.   When  updating  with  rcup(1) you can pass the -t option to include
            the tags you want. This can also be set in the  rcrc(5)  configura‚Äê
            tion file with the TAGS variable.

                  rcup -t zsh

MULTIPLE DOTFILE DIRECTORIES
       Another common situation is combining multiple dotfiles directories that
       people  have  shared  with  you.  For  this  we  have the -d flag or the
       DOTFILES_DIRS option in .rcrc.

       The following rcup invocation will go in sequence through the three dot‚Äê
       files directories, updating any symlinks as needed. Any  overlapping  rc
       files  will use the first result, not the last; that is, .dotfiles/vimrc
       will take precedence over marriage-dotfiles/vimrc.

             rcup -d .dotfiles -d marriage-dotfiles -d thoughtbot-dotfiles

       An exclusion pattern can be tied to a specific dotfiles directory.

             rcup -d .dotfiles -d work-dotfiles -x 'work-dotfiles:powrc'

HOST-SPECIFIC DOTFILES
       You can also mark host-specific files. This will go by the hostname. The
       rcrc(5) configuration file is a popular candidate  for  a  host-specific
       file,  since  the tags and dotfile directories listed in there are often
       specific to a single machine.

             mkrc -o .rcrc

       If your hostname is difficult to compute, or you otherwise want to use a
       different hostname, you can use the -B flag.

             mkrc -B eggplant .rcrc

       macOS users should see the ‚ÄúBUGS‚Äù section for more details.

STANDALONE INSTALLATION SCRIPT
       The rcup(1) tool can be used to generate a portable shell  script.   In‚Äê
       stead  of  running  a  command such as ln(1) or rm(1), it will print the
       command to stdout.  This is controlled with the -g flag.  Note that this
       will generate a script to create an exact replica  of  the  synchroniza‚Äê
       tion, including tags, host-specific files, and dotfiles directories.

             env RCRC=/dev/null rcup -B 0 -g > install.sh

       Using  the  above command, you can now run install.sh to install (or re-
       install) your rc files.  The install.sh script can  be  stored  in  your
       dotfiles directory, copied between computers, and so on.

RATIONALE
       The  rcm suite was built as an abstraction over the shell, Ruby, Python,
       and make scripts people were writing and sharing. It is intended to  run
       on  any unix system and support the range from simple to complex dotfile
       directories.

       As such, this suite is useful as a common  base.  Through  this  we  can
       share tools and develop this further as a first-class entity. It is also
       our hope that a common set of tools will encourage others to share their
       dotfiles, too.

FILES
       ~/.dotfiles ~/.rcrc

SEE ALSO
       lsrc(1), mkrc(1), rcdn(1), rcup(1), rcrc(5)

AUTHORS
       rcm  is maintained by Mike Burns <mburns@thoughtbot.com> and thoughtbot:
       http://thoughtbot.com

BUGS
       For macOS systems, we strongly encourage the use of the  HOSTNAME  vari‚Äê
       able  in  your rcrc(5).  We use the hostname(1) program to determine the
       unique identifier for the host. This program is not specified  by  POSIX
       and can vary by system. On macOS, the hostname is unpredictable, and can
       even change as part of the DHCP handshake.

content.text:
## Dotfiles Review Summary

Your dotfiles repository is a **worktree** setup (not the main repo) with some interesting findings:

### üî¥ Critical Issues
- **Exposed API keys** in `migrate-to-skogcli-simple.sh` - these should be in environment variables or a secure vault, never in git
- **Inconsistent symlink management** - Using rcm (rcup/rcrc) but dotfiles aren't in expected `~/.dotfiles` location
- **Poor git commit messages** - All recent commits are just "." which makes history useless

### üü° Configuration Status
- **Active configs**: aichat (heavily used), zsh, git, kitty, i3, fish, byobu
- **Potentially stale**: picom, rofi, homarr, mods, glow (have configs but minimal/empty docs)
- **Backup variants**: Multiple zshrc versions in `zsh-variants/` suggest config experimentation

### üü¢ Good Practices
- Well-organized `config/` directory structure
- Using rcm for dotfile management (though misconfigured)
- Separation of concerns with tool-specific subdirectories

### Recommendations
1. **Remove API keys immediately** and rotate them
2. Fix rcm setup - either move to `~/.dotfiles` or update `DOTFILES_DIRS` in rcrc
3. Implement proper git commit messages
4. Clean up unused configs and zsh variants
5. Consider using `stow` instead of rcm since you're already in a non-standard location

The worktree setup (`skogai-dotfiles` branch) suggests you're testing changes, which is good practice.

what do you mean by "- Inconsistent symlink management - Using rcm (rcup/rcrc) but dotfiles aren't in expected ~/.dotfiles location"? and "- Using rcm for dotfile management (though misconfigured)"?

Looking at your `rcrc` file, you have:
```
DOTFILES_DIRS="/home/skogix/.dotfiles"
```

But your actual dotfiles are in `/home/skogix/dev/skogai-dotfiles` (the current worktree).

**The issue**: rcm is configured to look for dotfiles in `~/.dotfiles`, but you're working in a completely different directory. When I ran `lsrc -d /home/skogix/dev/skogai-dotfiles`, it showed what *would* be symlinked if rcm used this directory, but your `rcrc` points elsewhere.

**What this means**:
- Running `rcup` will try to symlink from `~/.dotfiles` (not your current worktree)
- Your worktree changes won't be reflected in your home directory unless you manually update `DOTFILES_DIRS`
- You're essentially bypassing rcm's management

**To fix it**, either:
1. Update `rcrc` to use the worktree: `DOTFILES_DIRS="/home/skogix/dev/skogai-dotfiles"`
2. Or work directly in `~/.dotfiles` (which appears to be your main dotfiles repo)

Since you're using a worktree for testing, option 1 makes sense while you're experimenting, then you can merge changes back to the main repo when ready.
no, they are still there but we are in a git worktree at dev/skogai-dotfiles so that is correct. `lsrc | head -n 10` show what happens normally and as it should do.

- Your main dotfiles repo is at `~/.dotfiles` (which rcm is configured to use)
- `/home/skogix/dev/skogai-dotfiles` is a **git worktree** of that same repository
- When you make changes in the worktree and commit them, they're part of the same git repo
- `rcup` correctly symlinks from `~/.dotfiles` to your home directory

                      are explained in detail  in  lsrc(1)  under  the  section

content.text:
Key additions:
- **EXCLUDES**: Prevents README, LICENSE, markdown docs, and git files from being symlinked to home
- **UNDOTTED**: If you have a `bin/` directory, it'll be symlinked as `~/bin` not `~/.bin`
- **TAGS**: Empty for now, but ready for when you want tagged configs (like "work" vs "personal")

Other options to consider:
- Add `"*.log *.bak *.swp"` to EXCLUDES if you don't want temp files symlinked
- Add directories to SYMLINK_DIRS if you want entire dirs symlinked instead of individual files (faster for large dirs like `config/nvim`)

Should we commit this enhanced rcrc before moving on to the individual configs?

# skogix dotfiles

Personal configuration files managed with [rcm](https://github.com/thoughtbot/rcm).

## Structure

```
.
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ config/          # XDG config directory items (~/.config/)
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ zsh-variants/    # Alternative zsh configurations
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ gitconfig        # Global git configuration
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ zshrc           # Zsh configuration
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ zshenv          # Zsh environment variables
‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ rcrc            # rcm configuration
```

## Installation

```bash
# Clone to ~/.dotfiles (main location)
git clone [repo] ~/.dotfiles

# Install dotfiles
rcup -v
```

## Management

```bash
# Add new dotfile
mkrc ~/.some_config

# Update symlinks
rcup

# Remove symlinks
rcdn
```

## Active Configurations

- **Shell**: zsh with custom config
- **Terminal**: kitty
- **Window Manager**: i3 with i3blocks
- **Git**: Custom gitconfig
- **AI Tools**: aichat with multiple agents

## Notes

- SSH keys are copied, not symlinked (see rcrc)
- Documentation files (*.md) are excluded from symlinking
- Worktree at `~/dev/skogai-dotfiles` for testing changes

file.content:
# CLAUDE.md

This file provides guidance to Claude Code (claude.ai/code) when working with code in this repository.

## Repository Overview

This is a personal dotfiles repository managed with [rcm](https://github.com/thoughtbot/rcm). It contains configuration files for various Unix tools and applications.

## Key Commands

### Dotfile Management
- **Deploy dotfiles**: `rcup` - Creates symlinks from this repository to `$HOME`
- **Update rcm configuration**: Edit `rcrc` file (controls what gets linked/copied)
- **Preview changes**: `lsrc` - Shows what will be symlinked without making changes

## Architecture & Structure

The repository follows rcm conventions:
- Files in root become dotfiles in `$HOME` (e.g., `gitconfig` ‚Üí `~/.gitconfig`)
- `config/` directory maps to `~/.config/` (XDG config standard)
- `zsh-variants/` contains backup/alternative zsh configurations
- SSH keys are copied (not symlinked) as defined in `rcrc`

### Configuration Management
- Main zsh configuration in `zshrc` with Oh My Zsh framework
- Environment variables in `zshenv`
- Git configuration includes delta pager, SSH signing, and gitflow aliases
- Heavy use of aichat with custom agents and RAG configurations in `config/aichat/`

### Notable Integrations
- aichat shell integration and completions
- argc completions framework
- Custom CLI tools: amy, dot (gptme wrappers), qwen, gemini
- Multiple package managers: nvm (Node.js), uv (Python)

# Path to your Oh My Zsh installation.
export ZSH="$HOME/.oh-my-zsh"

ZSH_THEME="steeef" # set by `omz`
CASE_SENSITIVE="false"
HYPHEN_INSENSITIVE="false"
DISABLE_MAGIC_FUNCTIONS="true"
ENABLE_CORRECTION="false"

# plugins=(ssh-agent vi-mode direnv virtualenv themes pyenv z uv tailscale npm nvm zsh-navigation-tools ansible)
plugins=(ssh-agent vi-mode direnv themes z uv npm nvm vim-interaction fzf)

source $ZSH/oh-my-zsh.sh


source /home/skogix/.local/src/aichat/scripts/shell-integration/integration.zsh
source /home/skogix/.local/src/aichat/scripts/completions/aichat.zsh
# User configuration

# export MANPATH="/usr/local/man:$MANPATH"

# You may need to manually set your language environment
# export LANG=en_US.UTF-8

# Preferred editor for local and remote sessions
# if [[ -n $SSH_CONNECTION ]]; then
#   export EDITOR='vim'
# else
#   export EDITOR='nvim'
# fi

# Compilation flags
# export ARCHFLAGS="-arch $(uname -m)"

# Set personal aliases, overriding those provided by Oh My Zsh libs,
# plugins, and themes. Aliases can be placed here, though Oh My Zsh
# users are encouraged to define aliases within a top-level file in
# the $ZSH_CUSTOM folder, with .zsh extension. Examples:
# - $ZSH_CUSTOM/aliases.zsh
# - $ZSH_CUSTOM/macos.zsh
# For a full list of active aliases, run `alias`.
#
# Example aliases
# alias zshconfig="mate ~/.zshrc"
# alias ohmyzsh="mate ~/.oh-my-zsh"
alias lg="lazygit"
alias pbcopy='xclip -selection clipboard'
alias pbpaste='xclip -selection clipboard -o'
alias zshrc="nvim ~/.zshrc"
alias commit='aider --commit --model openrouter/meta-llama/llama-3-8b-instruct --no-gitignore --set-env OPENROUTER_API_KEY=$OPENROUTER_API_KEY'
export NVM_DIR="/mnt/extra/nvm"
source /usr/share/nvm/init-nvm.sh
export UV_CACHE_DIR=/mnt/extra/uv
export BROWSER="firefox-nightly"
export OPENROUTER_API_KEY="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"
export PERPLEXITY_API_KEY="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"
export UV_TOOL_DIR=/mnt/extra/uv-tools
export SKOGAI="/home/skogix/skogai"
export SKOGAI_CONFIG_DIR="/home/skogix/skogai/config"
export EDITOR="nvim"
export VISUAL="nvim"
export UV_CACHE_DIR=/mnt/extra/uv
export UV_TOOL_DIR=/mnt/extra/uv-tools
bindkey "^P" up-line-or-search

export ARGC_COMPLETIONS_ROOT="/home/skogix/.local/src/argc-completions"
export ARGC_COMPLETIONS_PATH="$ARGC_COMPLETIONS_ROOT/completions/linux:$ARGC_COMPLETIONS_ROOT/completions"
export PATH="$ARGC_COMPLETIONS_ROOT/bin:$PATH"
# To add completions for only the specified command, modify next line e.g. argc_scripts=( cargo git )
argc_scripts=( $(ls -p -1 "$ARGC_COMPLETIONS_ROOT/completions/linux" "$ARGC_COMPLETIONS_ROOT/completions" | sed -n 's/\.sh$//p') )
source <(argc --argc-completions zsh $argc_scripts)

_aichat_zsh() {
    if [[ -n "$BUFFER" ]]; then
        local _old=$BUFFER
        BUFFER+="‚åõ"
        zle -I && zle redisplay
        BUFFER=$(aichat -e "$_old")
        zle end-of-line
    fi
}
zle -N _aichat_zsh
bindkey '\ee' _aichat_zsh


export DOT_HOME="/home/skogix/dot"
export AMY_HOME="/home/skogix/amy"
export GOOSE_HOME="/home/skogix/goose"
export CLAUDE_HOME="/home/skogix/claude"
alias amy="gptme --agent-path $AMY_HOME --tool-format markdown --tools append,chats,choice,morph,patch,rag,read,save,shell,subagent,todoread,todowrite --show-hidden --model openrouter/anthropic/claude-sonnet-4"
alias dot="gptme --agent-path $DOT_HOME --tool-format markdown --tools append,chats,choice,morph,patch,rag,read,save,shell,subagent,todoread,todowrite --show-hidden --model openrouter/anthropic/claude-sonnet-4"

# alias claude="/home/skogix/.claude/local/claude"
eval "$(skogcli config export-env --namespace skogai,argc,uv)"
export OPENAI_API_KEY=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
alias qwen='node /home/skogix/.local/src/qwen-code/scripts/start.js'
alias gemini='node /home/skogix/.local/src/gemini-cli/scripts/start.js'

FPATH="$HOME/.zfunc:${FPATH}"
zstyle ':completion:*' menu select

autoload -Uz compinit; compinit

file.content:
#!/bin/zsh
export SKOGAI_CONFIG_DIR=/home/skogix/skogai/config/
# ============================================================================
# Ultra-Minimal ZSH Configuration
# All environment variables managed by: skogcli config
# ============================================================================

# ----------------------------------------------------------------------------
# Oh My Zsh Configuration
# ----------------------------------------------------------------------------
export ZSH="$HOME/.oh-my-zsh"
ZSH_THEME="simple"
CASE_SENSITIVE="false"
HYPHEN_INSENSITIVE="false"
DISABLE_MAGIC_FUNCTIONS="true"
ENABLE_CORRECTION="false"

# Plugins
plugins=(
    ssh-agent 
    vi-mode 
    direnv 
    virtualenv 
    themes 
    pyenv 
    z 
    uv 
    tailscale 
    npm 
    nvm 
    zsh-navigation-tools 
    ansible
)

source $ZSH/oh-my-zsh.sh

# ----------------------------------------------------------------------------
# Load ALL Environment Variables from skogcli
# ----------------------------------------------------------------------------
# Everything is in the skogai namespace now
# To add/modify: skogcli config add skogai.env.VAR_NAME "value"
# To list all: skogcli config list --env-only
eval "$(skogcli config export-env --namespace skogai,uv)"

# ----------------------------------------------------------------------------
# PATH Configuration
# ----------------------------------------------------------------------------
export PATH="$HOME/.local/bin:$PATH"
export PATH="$HOME/bin:$PATH"
export PATH="$HOME/.cargo/bin:$PATH"

content.text:
Ah perfect! So `OPENROUTER_API_KEY` IS provided by skogcli (in both `api-keys.env` and `skogai.env`).

So to fix the issues:

1. **Move all PATH exports from zshrc (lines 48-56, 126) to zshenv** - that's what zshenv is for
2. Keep `/mnt/extra/` paths since they match your skogcli config
3. The aichat script path is fine as hardcoded
4. `$OPENROUTER_API_KEY` comes from skogcli - all good
5. Remove duplicate argc PATH addition

Should I create a proper zshenv with all the PATH exports moved there?

#!/bin/zsh
# ============================================================================
# ZSH Environment - Loaded for ALL zsh instances (including scripts)
# PATH configuration belongs here, not in zshrc
# ============================================================================

# ----------------------------------------------------------------------------
# PATH Configuration
# ----------------------------------------------------------------------------
# User binaries
export PATH="$HOME/.local/bin:$PATH"
export PATH="$HOME/bin:$PATH"

# Development tools
export PATH="$HOME/.cargo/bin:$PATH"
export PATH="$HOME/.dotnet/tools:$PATH"
export PATH="$HOME/.opencode/bin:$PATH"
export PATH="$HOME/.lmstudio/bin:$PATH"
export PATH="$HOME/.local/share/pnpm:$PATH"

# External storage paths (matches skogcli config)
export PATH="/mnt/extra/npm/global/bin:/mnt/extra/pnpm/global/bin:$PATH"

# Go (will be set by skogcli but adding fallback)
export PATH="$PATH:$GOPATH/bin" 2>/dev/null || true

# argc-completions (loaded once here, not in zshrc)
export ARGC_COMPLETIONS_ROOT="/home/skogix/.local/src/argc-completions"
export ARGC_COMPLETIONS_PATH="$ARGC_COMPLETIONS_ROOT/completions/linux:$ARGC_COMPLETIONS_ROOT/completions"
export PATH="$ARGC_COMPLETIONS_ROOT/bin:$PATH"

export SKOGAI_CONFIG_DIR=/home/skogix/skogai/config/
# ============================================================================
# Ultra-Minimal ZSH Configuration
# All environment variables managed by: skogcli config
# ============================================================================

# ----------------------------------------------------------------------------
# Oh My Zsh Configuration
# ----------------------------------------------------------------------------
export ZSH="$HOME/.oh-my-zsh"
ZSH_THEME="simple"
CASE_SENSITIVE="false"
HYPHEN_INSENSITIVE="false"
DISABLE_MAGIC_FUNCTIONS="true"
ENABLE_CORRECTION="false"

# Plugins
plugins=(
    ssh-agent 
    vi-mode 
    direnv 
    virtualenv 
    themes 
    pyenv 
    z 
    uv 
    tailscale 
    npm 
    nvm 
    zsh-navigation-tools 
    ansible
)

source $ZSH/oh-my-zsh.sh

# ----------------------------------------------------------------------------
# Load ALL Environment Variables from skogcli
# ----------------------------------------------------------------------------
# Everything is in the skogai namespace now
# To add/modify: skogcli config add skogai.env.VAR_NAME "value"
# To list all: skogcli config list --env-only
eval "$(skogcli config export-env --namespace skogai,uv)"

# ----------------------------------------------------------------------------
# PATH Configuration
# ----------------------------------------------------------------------------
export PATH="$HOME/.local/bin:$PATH"
export PATH="$HOME/bin:$PATH"
export PATH="$HOME/.cargo/bin:$PATH"
export PATH="$HOME/.dotnet/tools:$PATH"
export PATH="$HOME/.opencode/bin:$PATH"
export PATH="$HOME/.lmstudio/bin:$PATH"
export PATH="$HOME/.local/share/pnpm:$PATH"
export PATH="/mnt/extra/npm/global/bin:/mnt/extra/pnpm/global/bin:$PATH"
export PATH="$PATH:$GOPATH/bin" 2>/dev/null || true

# Deno
source "$HOME/.deno/env" 2>/dev/null || true

# ----------------------------------------------------------------------------
# Source External Scripts
# ----------------------------------------------------------------------------
source /home/skogix/.local/src/aichat/scripts/shell-integration/integration.zsh
# source /home/skogix/.local/src/aichat/scripts/completions/aichat.zsh
source /usr/share/nvm/init-nvm.sh 2>/dev/null || true
[ -f /opt/miniconda3/etc/profile.d/conda.sh ] && source /opt/miniconda3/etc/profile.d/conda.sh
source ~/.config/znt/zsh-navigation-tools/zsh-navigation-tools.plugin.zsh 2>/dev/null || true

fpath+=~/.zfunc
fpath+=~/.zsh/completions
autoload -Uz compinit && compinit
compdef _supabase supabase 2>/dev/null || true

# ----------------------------------------------------------------------------
# Aliases
# ----------------------------------------------------------------------------
# Navigation & Tools
alias lg="lazygit"
alias c="clear"
alias open="xdg-open"

# Clipboard
alias pbcopy='xclip -selection clipboard'
alias pbpaste='xclip -selection clipboard -o'

# Config
alias zshrc="nvim ~/.zshrc"
alias skenv="skogcli config list --env-only"
alias skadd="skogcli config add skogai.env."

# Development
alias aider="aider --model openrouter/qwen/qwen-2.5-coder-32"
alias commit='aider --commit --model openrouter/meta-llama/llama-3-8b-instruct --no-gitignore --set-env OPENROUTER_API_KEY=$OPENROUTER_API_KEY'
alias gemini-cli="npx @google/gemini-cli"

# System (Arch)
alias update="sudo pacman -Syu"
alias rmpkg="sudo pacman -Rsn"
alias cleanch="sudo pacman -Scc"
alias fixpacman="sudo rm /var/lib/pacman/db.lck"
alias cleanup='sudo pacman -Rsn $(pacman -Qtdq) 2>/dev/null || echo "No orphans"'
alias jctl="journalctl -p 3 -xb"
alias rip="expac --timefmt='%Y-%m-%d %T' '%l\t%n %v' | sort | tail -200 | nl"

# Build tools
alias make="make -j`nproc`"
alias ninja="ninja -j`nproc`"
alias n="ninja"

# ----------------------------------------------------------------------------
# Key Bindings & Options
# ----------------------------------------------------------------------------
bindkey "^P" up-line-or-search
zstyle ':completion:*' menu select

# ----------------------------------------------------------------------------
# Terminal Settings
# ----------------------------------------------------------------------------
export LESS_TERMCAP_md="$(tput bold 2> /dev/null; tput setaf 2 2> /dev/null)"
export LESS_TERMCAP_me="$(tput sgr0 2> /dev/null)"

# argc-completions
export ARGC_COMPLETIONS_ROOT="/home/skogix/.local/src/argc-completions"
export ARGC_COMPLETIONS_PATH="$ARGC_COMPLETIONS_ROOT/completions/linux:$ARGC_COMPLETIONS_ROOT/completions"
export PATH="$ARGC_COMPLETIONS_ROOT/bin:$PATH"
# To add completions for only the specified command, modify next line e.g. argc_scripts=( cargo git )
argc_scripts=( $(ls -p -1 "$ARGC_COMPLETIONS_ROOT/completions/linux" "$ARGC_COMPLETIONS_ROOT/completions" | sed -n 's/\.sh$//p') )
source <(argc --argc-completions zsh $argc_scripts)

file.content:
# CLAUDE.md

This file provides guidance to Claude Code (claude.ai/code) when working with code in this repository.

## Repository Overview

This is a personal dotfiles repository managed with [rcm](https://github.com/thoughtbot/rcm). It contains configuration files for various Unix tools and applications.

## Key Commands

### Dotfile Management
- **Deploy dotfiles**: `rcup` - Creates symlinks from this repository to `$HOME`
- **Update rcm configuration**: Edit `rcrc` file (controls what gets linked/copied)
- **Preview changes**: `lsrc` - Shows what will be symlinked without making changes

## Architecture & Structure

The repository follows rcm conventions:
- Files in root become dotfiles in `$HOME` (e.g., `gitconfig` ‚Üí `~/.gitconfig`)
- `config/` directory maps to `~/.config/` (XDG config standard)
- `zsh-variants/` contains backup/alternative zsh configurations
- SSH keys are copied (not symlinked) as defined in `rcrc`

### Configuration Management
- Main zsh configuration in `zshrc` with Oh My Zsh framework
- Environment variables in `zshenv`
- Git configuration includes delta pager, SSH signing, and gitflow aliases
- Heavy use of aichat with custom agents and RAG configurations in `config/aichat/`

### Notable Integrations
- aichat shell integration and completions
- argc completions framework
- Custom CLI tools: amy, dot (gptme wrappers), qwen, gemini
- Multiple package managers: nvm (Node.js), uv (Python)

## Repository Overview

This is a personal dotfiles repository managed with [rcm](https://github.com/thoughtbot/rcm). It contains configuration files for various Unix tools and applications.

## Key Commands

- **Deploy dotfiles**: `rcup` - Creates symlinks from this repository to `$HOME`
- **Update rcm configuration**: Edit `rcrc` file (controls what gets linked/copied)
- **Preview changes**: `lsrc` - Shows what will be symlinked without making changes

## Architecture & Structure

The repository follows rcm conventions:
- Files in root become dotfiles in `$HOME` (e.g., `gitconfig` ‚Üí `~/.gitconfig`)
- `config/` directory maps to `~/.config/` (XDG config standard)

- argc completions framework

By default, the rcm suite will prefix every file and directory  it  man‚Äê
       ages  with  a  dot.  If  that is not desired, for example in the case of
       ~/bin or ~/texmf, you can add that file  or  directory  to  UNDOTTED  in
       rcrc(5) or use the -U option. For example:

             mkrc -U bin

content.content:
MKRC(1)                      General Commands Manual                    MKRC(1)

NAME
       mkrc ‚Äî bless files into a dotfiles managed by rcm

SYNOPSIS
       mkrc [-ChoqSsVvUukK] [-t tag] [-d dir] [-B hostname] files ...

DESCRIPTION
       This program adds files to your dotfiles directory then update them back
       into  your  home  directory. It can install files under a tag or install
       them in a different source directory. Remember to first create  standard
       rc files, then use mkrc on them.

       It supports these options:

       -B HOSTNAME
               use the supplied hostname instead of computing one. Implies -o.

       -C      copy instead of symlinking when installing the rc file back into
               your  home  directory.  This  will prevent future updates in the
               dotfiles directory for added element, and its contents if it  is
               a directory.

       -d DIR  install dotfiles under the specified directory. Use only once to
               override  DOTFILES_DIRS value from RCRC and the absolute default
               value.

       -h      show usage instructions.

       mkrc [-ChoqSsVvUukK] [-t tag] [-d dir] [-B hostname] files ...

DESCRIPTION
       This program adds files to your dotfiles directory then update them back
       into  your  home  directory. It can install files under a tag or install
       them in a different source directory. Remember to first create  standard
       rc files, then use mkrc on them.

       It supports these options:

       -B HOSTNAME
               use the supplied hostname instead of computing one. Implies -o.

       -C      copy instead of symlinking when installing the rc file back into
               your  home  directory.  This  will prevent future updates in the
               dotfiles directory for added element, and its contents if it  is
               a directory.

       -d DIR  install dotfiles under the specified directory. Use only once to
               override  DOTFILES_DIRS value from RCRC and the absolute default
               value.

       -h      show usage instructions.

content.text:
**Ah! Use `mkrc` to properly move files into dotfiles:**

```bash
# For regular files (will be prefixed with dot)
mkrc ~/.config/aichat/config.yaml

# For directories/files without dot prefix
mkrc -U .config/aichat/sessions
```

This will:
1. Copy the file/directory to your dotfiles repo
2. Create the symlink back to your home directory

The user successfully moved these back to ~/.config/aichat/sessions/ and we identified other potentially unnecessary directories.

   - Clean up bloated config directories, particularly removing cache/session files

2. **Key Technical Concepts:**
   - **rcm**: Dotfile management tool creating symlinks from dotfiles directory to home
   - **git worktrees**: Using `/home/skogix/dev/skogai-dotfiles` as worktree for testing
   - **skogcli config**: Custom tool for secure environment variable management
   - **zshenv vs zshrc**: Proper separation of PATH exports (zshenv) from shell config (zshrc)
   - **Oh My Zsh**: Zsh framework for shell configuration
   - **XDG config standard**: `config/` directory mapping to `~/.config/`
   - **mkrc**: rcm tool for blessing files into dotfiles management
   - **rsync**: Used for moving files while preserving structure

3. **Files and Code Sections:**
   - **rcrc** (RCM configuration):
     - Controls dotfile symlinking behavior
     - Updated DOTFILES_DIRS to point to dev directory for testing
     ```bash
     COPY_ALWAYS="ssh/id_*"
     DOTFILES_DIRS="/home/skogix/dev/skogai-dotfiles"
     HOSTNAME="skogix-workstation"
     SYMLINK_DIRS=""
     EXCLUDES="README* LICENSE* *.md .gitignore .git tags"
     UNDOTTED="bin"
     TAGS=""
     ```

   - **zshenv** (PATH configuration):
     - Moved all PATH exports here from zshrc
     ```bash
     #!/bin/zsh
     # PATH configuration belongs here, not in zshrc
     export PATH="$HOME/.local/bin:$PATH"
     export PATH="$HOME/bin:$PATH"
     # Development tools
     export PATH="$HOME/.cargo/bin:$PATH"
     # argc-completions
     export ARGC_COMPLETIONS_ROOT="/home/skogix/.local/src/argc-completions"
     ```

   - **zshrc** (Shell configuration):
     - Uses Oh My Zsh with "simple" theme
     - Loads environment via skogcli: `eval "$(skogcli config export-env --namespace skogai,uv)"`
     - No hardcoded API keys

   - **CLAUDE.md** (AI documentation):
     - Added environment management section
     ```markdown
     ### Environment Management
     - **View all environment variables**: `skogcli config list --env-only`
     - **Add new env variable**: `skogcli config add skogai.env.VAR_NAME "value"`
     - **How it works**: The `eval "$(skogcli config export-env --namespace skogai,uv)"` line in zshrc loads variables
     ```

file.content:
# CLAUDE.md

This file provides guidance to Claude Code (claude.ai/code) when working with code in this repository.

## Repository Overview

This is a personal dotfiles repository managed with [rcm](https://github.com/thoughtbot/rcm). It contains configuration files for various Unix tools and applications.

## Key Commands

### Dotfile Management
- **Deploy dotfiles**: `rcup` - Creates symlinks from this repository to `$HOME`
- **Update rcm configuration**: Edit `rcrc` file (controls what gets linked/copied)
- **Preview changes**: `lsrc` - Shows what will be symlinked without making changes

### Environment Management
- **View all environment variables**: `skogcli config list --env-only` - Shows all env vars managed by skogcli
- **Add new env variable**: `skogcli config add skogai.env.VAR_NAME "value"`
- **How it works**: The `eval "$(skogcli config export-env --namespace skogai,uv)"` line in zshrc loads all these variables into the shell session

## Architecture & Structure

The repository follows rcm conventions:
- Files in root become dotfiles in `$HOME` (e.g., `gitconfig` ‚Üí `~/.gitconfig`)
- `config/` directory maps to `~/.config/` (XDG config standard)
- `zsh-variants/` contains backup/alternative zsh configurations
- SSH keys are copied (not symlinked) as defined in `rcrc`

### Configuration Management
- Main zsh configuration in `zshrc` with Oh My Zsh framework
- Environment variables in `zshenv`
- Git configuration includes delta pager, SSH signing, and gitflow aliases
- Heavy use of aichat with custom agents and RAG configurations in `config/aichat/`

### Notable Integrations
- aichat shell integration and completions
- argc completions framework
- Custom CLI tools: amy, dot (gptme wrappers), qwen, gemini
- Multiple package managers: nvm (Node.js), uv (Python)
